div.l: A prentys sūmtyme duelled in oure cite A 4365
And of a craft of vitayles was he
Gaylard he was as gold smyth in chawe
Broune as a bery a ꝓpropre short felawe
Wᵗith lockes blake kempt ful fetysly
Daunce he couthe ful well ⁊and Iolely
Þat he was cleped ꝑperkyn reueloᵘur
He was as ful of loue ⁊and ꝑparamoᵘur
As is þᵉ hyve full of hony swete
Well was þᵉ wenche wᵗith hym myth mete
At eủery brydale wolde he synge ⁊and hop
He loued bett̉er þᵉ tauerne þan þᵉ shop
For whenne any rydynge was in þᵉ chepe
Out of þᵉ shop þyd̉er wolde he lepe
Tyl þᵗat he had al þᵉ syht yseyn
And daunced well he wolde not come agayn
To hop ⁊and syng ⁊and make such desport 4382
He gadered hym a meyne of his sort 4381
And þen þey sette steuene forte mete
To pleyen at þᵉ dyes in such a strete To hop
For in þᵉ Cite was non̄ app̉rentys
Þat fayrer couth cast a peyre of dys
Þan ꝑperkyn couth ⁊and þ̉erto he was free
Of his despence in place of pⁱriuete
Þat fond his mayst̉er wel in his chaffare
For often tyme he fond his his box bare 4390
For syker a p̉rentys a reuelour
Þat haunteth deys ryot or ꝑparamoᵘur
His mayst̉er shal hit in his shop aby
Al haue he no part of þᵉ mynstralcy
